    "deletions": 152,
    "changes": 152,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/b1772664f37c7db5cad5125016b2bad841d5d0aa/docs%2Fidentity%2Fsaas-apps%2Fgithub-ae-provisioning-tutorial.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/b1772664f37c7db5cad5125016b2bad841d5d0aa/docs%2Fidentity%2Fsaas-apps%2Fgithub-ae-provisioning-tutorial.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Fsaas-apps%2Fgithub-ae-provisioning-tutorial.md?ref=b1772664f37c7db5cad5125016b2bad841d5d0aa",
    "patch": "@@ -1,152 +0,0 @@\n----\n-title: Configure GitHub AE for automatic user provisioning with Microsoft Entra ID\n-description: Learn how to automatically provision and de-provision user accounts from Microsoft Entra ID to GitHub AE.\n-\n-\n-author: jeevansd\n-manager: pmwongera\n-\n-ms.service: entra-id\n-ms.subservice: saas-apps\n-\n-\n-ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 03/25/2025\n-ms.author: jeedes\n-\n-# Customer intent: As an IT administrator, I want to learn how to automatically provision and deprovision user accounts from Microsoft Entra ID to GitHub AE so that I can streamline the user management process and ensure that users have the appropriate access to GitHub AE.\n----\n-\n-# Configure GitHub AE for automatic user provisioning with Microsoft Entra ID\n-\n-This article describes the steps you need to perform in both GitHub AE and Microsoft Entra ID to configure automatic user provisioning. When configured, Microsoft Entra ID automatically provisions and de-provisions users and/or groups to GitHub AE using the Microsoft Entra provisioning service. For important details on what this service does, how it works, and frequently asked questions, see [Automate user provisioning and deprovisioning to SaaS applications with Microsoft Entra ID](~/identity/app-provisioning/user-provisioning.md). \n-\n-\n-## Capabilities supported\n-> [!div class=\"checklist\"]\n-> * Create users in GitHub AE\n-> * Remove users in GitHub AE when they don't require access anymore\n-> * Keep user attributes synchronized between Microsoft Entra ID and GitHub AE\n-> * Provision groups and group memberships in GitHub AE\n-> * Single sign-on to [GitHub AE](./github-ae-tutorial.md) (recommended)\n-\n-## Prerequisites\n-\n-The scenario outlined in this article assumes that you already have the following prerequisites:\n-\n-[!INCLUDE [common-prerequisites.md](~/identity/saas-apps/includes/common-prerequisites.md)]\n-* GitHub AE, fully [initialized](https://docs.github.com/github-ae@latest/admin/configuration/initializing-github-ae) and configured for login with [SAML SSO](https://docs.github.com/github-ae@latest/admin/authentication/configuring-authentication-and-provisioning-for-your-enterprise-using-azure-ad) through your Microsoft Entra tenant.\n-\n-## Step 1: Plan your provisioning deployment\n-1. Learn about [how the provisioning service works](~/identity/app-provisioning/user-provisioning.md).\n-2. Determine who's in [scope for provisioning](~/identity/app-provisioning/define-conditional-rules-for-provisioning-user-accounts.md).\n-3. Determine what data to [map between Microsoft Entra ID and GitHub AE](~/identity/app-provisioning/customize-application-attributes.md). \n-\n-<a name='step-2-configure-github-ae-to-support-provisioning-with-azure-ad'></a>\n-\n-## Step 2: Configure GitHub AE to support provisioning with Microsoft Entra ID\n-\n-Learn how to enable provisioning for GitHub AE [here](https://docs.github.com/github-ae@latest/admin/authentication/configuring-user-provisioning-for-your-enterprise).\n-\n-<a name='step-3-add-github-ae-from-the-azure-ad-application-gallery'></a>\n-\n-## Step 3: Add GitHub AE from the Microsoft Entra application gallery\n-\n-Add GitHub AE from the Microsoft Entra application gallery to start managing provisioning to GitHub AE. If you have previously setup GitHub AE for SSO, you can use the same application. However, we recommend that you create a separate app when testing out the integration initially. Learn more about adding an application from the gallery [here](~/identity/enterprise-apps/add-application-portal.md). \n-\n-## Step 4: Define who is in scope for provisioning \n-\n-[!INCLUDE [create-assign-users-provisioning.md](~/identity/saas-apps/includes/create-assign-users-provisioning.md)]\n-\n-## Step 5: Configure automatic user provisioning to GitHub AE \n-\n-This section guides you through the steps to configure the Microsoft Entra provisioning service to create, update, and disable users and/or groups in TestApp based on user and/or group assignments in Microsoft Entra ID.\n-\n-<a name='to-configure-automatic-user-provisioning-for-github-ae-in-azure-ad'></a>\n-\n-### To configure automatic user provisioning for GitHub AE in Microsoft Entra ID:\n-\n-1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com) as at least a [Cloud Application Administrator](~/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#cloud-application-administrator).\n-1. Browse to **Entra ID** > **Enterprise apps**\n-\n-\t![Enterprise applications blade](common/enterprise-applications.png)\n-\n-1. In the applications list, select **GitHub AE**.\n-\n-\t![The GitHub AE link in the Applications list](common/all-applications.png)\n-\n-3. Select the **Provisioning** tab.\n-\n-\t![Provisioning tab](common/provisioning.png)\n-\n-4. Set the **Provisioning Mode** to **Automatic**.\n-\n-\t![Provisioning tab automatic](common/provisioning-automatic.png)\n-\n-5. Under the **Admin Credentials** section, input your GitHub AE **Tenant URL** and **Secret Token** retrieved earlier from Step 2. Select **Test Connection** to ensure Microsoft Entra ID can connect to GitHub AE. If the connection fails, ensure your GitHub AE account has Admin permissions and try again.\n-\n-\t![Token](common/provisioning-testconnection-tenanturltoken.png)\n-\n-6. In the **Notification Email** field, enter the email address of a person or group who should receive the provisioning error notifications and select the **Send an email notification when a failure occurs** check box.\n-\n-\t![Notification Email](common/provisioning-notification-email.png)\n-\n-7. Select **Save**.\n-\n-8. Under the **Mappings** section, select **Synchronize Microsoft Entra users** to **GitHub AE**.\n-\n-9. Review the user attributes that are synchronized from Microsoft Entra ID to GitHub AE in the **Attribute-Mapping** section. The attributes selected as **Matching** properties are used to match the user accounts in GitHub AE for update operations. If you choose to change the [matching target attribute](~/identity/app-provisioning/customize-application-attributes.md), you need to ensure that the GitHub AE API supports filtering users based on that attribute. Select the **Save** button to commit any changes.\n-\n-   |Attribute|Type|\n-   |---|---|\n-   |userName|String|\n-   |externalId|String|\n-   |emails[type eq \"work\"].value|String|\n-   |active|Boolean|\n-   |name.givenName|String|\n-   |name.familyName|String|\n-   |name.formatted|String|\n-   |displayName|String|\n-\n-10. Under the **Mappings** section, select **Synchronize Microsoft Entra groups to GitHub AE**.\n-\n-11. Review the group attributes that are synchronized from Microsoft Entra ID to GitHub AE in the **Attribute-Mapping** section. The attributes selected as **Matching** properties are used to match the groups in GitHub AE for update operations. Select the **Save** button to commit any changes.\n-\n-      |Attribute|Type|\n-      |---|---|\n-      |displayName|String|\n-      |externalId|String|\n-      |members|Reference|\n-\n-12. To configure scoping filters, refer to the following instructions provided in the [Scoping filter  article](~/identity/app-provisioning/define-conditional-rules-for-provisioning-user-accounts.md).\n-\n-13. To enable the Microsoft Entra provisioning service for GitHub AE, change the **Provisioning Status** to **On** in the **Settings** section.\n-\n-\t![Provisioning Status Toggled On](common/provisioning-toggle-on.png)\n-\n-14. Define the users and/or groups that you would like to provision to GitHub AE by choosing the desired values in **Scope** in the **Settings** section.\n-\n-\t![Provisioning Scope](common/provisioning-scope.png)\n-\n-15. When you're ready to provision, select **Save**.\n-\n-\t![Saving Provisioning Configuration](common/provisioning-configuration-save.png)\n-\n-This operation starts the initial synchronization cycle of all users and/or groups defined in **Scope** in the **Settings** section. The initial cycle takes longer to perform than subsequent cycles, which occur approximately every 40 minutes as long as the Microsoft Entra provisioning service is running. \n-\n-## Step 6: Monitor your deployment\n-\n-[!INCLUDE [monitor-deployment.md](~/identity/saas-apps/includes/monitor-deployment.md)]\n-\n-## Change log\n-\n-* 02/18/2021 - Added support for Groups provisioning.\n-\n-## Additional resources\n-\n-* [Managing user account provisioning for Enterprise Apps](~/identity/app-provisioning/configure-automatic-user-provisioning-portal.md)\n-* [What is application access and single sign-on with Microsoft Entra ID?](~/identity/enterprise-apps/what-is-single-sign-on.md)\n-\n-## Related content\n-\n-* [Learn how to review logs and get reports on provisioning activity](~/identity/app-provisioning/check-status-user-account-provisioning.md)"
  },

    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/caaf7d91e69ef3fd9d79b3845e84058a5ca4618c/docs%2Fidentity%2Fsaas-apps%2Fgithub-enterprise-server-provisioning-tutorial.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Fsaas-apps%2Fgithub-enterprise-server-provisioning-tutorial.md?ref=caaf7d91e69ef3fd9d79b3845e84058a5ca4618c",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,153 @@\n+---\n+title: Configure GitHub Enterprise Server for Automatic User Provisioning with Microsoft Entra ID\n+description: Learn how to automatically provision and de-provision user accounts from Microsoft Entra ID to GitHub Enterprise Server.\n+author: jeevansd\n+manager: mwongerapk\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.subservice: saas-apps\n+ms.topic: how-to\n+ms.date: 03/25/2025\n+ms.author: jeedes\n+\n+# Customer intent: As an IT administrator, I want to learn how to automatically provision and deprovision user accounts from Microsoft Entra ID to GitHub Enterprise Server so that I can streamline the user management process and ensure that users have the appropriate access to GitHub Enterprise Server.\n+---\n+\n+# Configure GitHub Enterprise Server for automatic user provisioning with Microsoft Entra ID\n+\n+This article describes the steps you need to perform in both GitHub Enterprise Server and Microsoft Entra ID to configure automatic user provisioning. When configured, Microsoft Entra ID automatically provisions and de-provisions users and/or groups to GitHub Enterprise Server using the Microsoft Entra provisioning service. For important details on what this service does, how it works, and frequently asked questions, see [Automate user provisioning and deprovisioning to SaaS applications with Microsoft Entra ID](~/identity/app-provisioning/user-provisioning.md). \n+\n+\n+## Capabilities supported\n+> [!div class=\"checklist\"]\n+> * Create users in GitHub Enterprise Server\n+> * Remove users in GitHub Enterprise Server when they don't require access anymore\n+> * Keep user attributes synchronized between Microsoft Entra ID and GitHub Enterprise Server\n+> * Provision groups and group memberships in GitHub Enterprise Server\n+> * Single sign-on to [GitHub Enterprise Server](./github-enterprise-server-tutorial.md) (recommended)\n+\n+## Prerequisites\n+\n+The scenario outlined in this article assumes that you already have the following prerequisites:\n+\n+[!INCLUDE [common-prerequisites.md](~/identity/saas-apps/includes/common-prerequisites.md)]\n+* GitHub Enterprise Server, fully [initialized](https://docs.github.com/enterprise-server/admin/overview/about-github-enterprise-server) and configured for login with [SAML SSO](https://docs.github.com/enterprise-server/admin/managing-iam/using-saml-for-enterprise-iam/configuring-saml-single-sign-on-for-your-enterprise) through your Microsoft Entra tenant.\n+\n+## Step 1: Plan your provisioning deployment\n+1. Learn about [how the provisioning service works](~/identity/app-provisioning/user-provisioning.md).\n+1. Determine who's in [scope for provisioning](~/identity/app-provisioning/define-conditional-rules-for-provisioning-user-accounts.md).\n+1. Determine what data to [map between Microsoft Entra ID and GitHub Enterprise Server](~/identity/app-provisioning/customize-application-attributes.md). \n+\n+<a name='step-2-configure-github-server-to-support-provisioning-with-azure-ad'></a>\n+\n+## Step 2: Configure GitHub Enterprise Server to support provisioning with Microsoft Entra ID\n+\n+Learn how to enable provisioning for GitHub Enterprise Server [here](https://docs.github.com/enterprise-server/admin/managing-iam/provisioning-user-accounts-with-scim/configuring-scim-provisioning-for-users).\n+\n+<a name='step-3-add-github-server-from-the-azure-ad-application-gallery'></a>\n+\n+## Step 3: Add GitHub Enterprise Server from the Microsoft Entra application gallery\n+\n+Add GitHub Enterprise Server from the Microsoft Entra application gallery to start managing provisioning to GitHub Enterprise Server. If you have previously setup GitHub Enterprise Server for SSO, you can use the same application. However, we recommend that you create a separate app when testing out the integration initially. Learn more about adding an application from the gallery [here](~/identity/enterprise-apps/add-application-portal.md). \n+\n+## Step 4: Define who is in scope for provisioning \n+\n+[!INCLUDE [create-assign-users-provisioning.md](~/identity/saas-apps/includes/create-assign-users-provisioning.md)]\n+\n+## Step 5: Configure automatic user provisioning to GitHub Enterprise Server \n+\n+This section guides you through the steps to configure the Microsoft Entra provisioning service to create, update, and disable users and/or groups in TestApp based on user and/or group assignments in Microsoft Entra ID.\n+\n+<a name='to-configure-automatic-user-provisioning-for-github-server-in-azure-ad'></a>\n+\n+### To configure automatic user provisioning for GitHub Enterprise Server in Microsoft Entra ID:\n+\n+1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com) as at least a [Cloud Application Administrator](~/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#cloud-application-administrator).\n+1. Browse to **Entra ID** > **Enterprise apps**\n+\n+    ![Screenshot of the Enterprise applications blade.](common/enterprise-applications.png)\n+\n+1. In the applications list, select **GitHub Enterprise Server**.\n+\n+    ![Screenshot of the GitHub Enterprise Server link highlighted in the Applications list.](common/all-applications.png)\n+\n+1. Select the **Provisioning** tab.\n+\n+    ![Screenshot of the Provisioning tab selected in the application menu.](common/provisioning.png)\n+\n+1. Set the **Provisioning Mode** to **Automatic**.\n+\n+    ![Screenshot of the Provisioning Mode dropdown set to Automatic.](common/provisioning-automatic.png)\n+\n+1. Under the **Admin Credentials** section, input your GitHub Enterprise Server **Tenant URL** and **Secret Token**. The values of the fields are in the following format:\n+\n+    * **Tenant URL**: `https://<your-github-server-domain>/api/v3/scim`\n+    * **Secret Token**: [The Personal Access Token (PAT)](https://docs.github.com/enterprise-server/admin/managing-iam/provisioning-user-accounts-with-scim/configuring-scim-provisioning-for-users#2-create-a-personal-access-token) you created for [the provisioning account](https://docs.github.com/enterprise-server/admin/managing-iam/provisioning-user-accounts-with-scim/configuring-scim-provisioning-for-users#1-create-a-built-in-setup-user) in your GitHub Enterprise Server instance.\n+\n+    Select **Test Connection** to ensure Microsoft Entra ID can connect to GitHub Enterprise Server. If the connection fails, ensure your GitHub Enterprise Server account has Admin permissions and try again.\n+\n+    ![Screenshot of the tenant URL and secret token fields with a Test Connection button.](common/provisioning-testconnection-tenanturltoken.png)\n+\n+1. In the **Notification Email** field, enter the email address of a person or group who should receive the provisioning error notifications and select the **Send an email notification when a failure occurs** check box.\n+\n+    ![Screenshot of the Notification Email field and checkbox for email notifications.](common/provisioning-notification-email.png)\n+\n+1. Select **Save**.\n+\n+1. Under the **Mappings** section, select **Provision Microsoft Entra ID Users**.\n+\n+1. Review the user attributes that are synchronized from Microsoft Entra ID to GitHub Enterprise Server in the **Attribute-Mapping** section. The attributes selected as **Matching** properties are used to match the user accounts in GitHub Enterprise Server for update operations. If you choose to change the [matching target attribute](~/identity/app-provisioning/customize-application-attributes.md), you need to ensure that the GitHub Enterprise Server API supports filtering users based on that attribute. Select the **Save** button to commit any changes.\n+\n+    |Attribute|Type|\n+    |---|---|\n+    |`userName`|String|\n+    |`externalId`|String|\n+    |`emails[type eq \"work\"].value`|String|\n+    |`active`|Boolean|\n+    |`name.givenName`|String|\n+    |`name.familyName`|String|\n+    |n`ame.formatted`|String|\n+    |`displayName`|String|\n+\n+1. Under the **Mappings** section, select **Provision Microsoft Entra ID Groups**.\n+\n+1. Review the group attributes that are synchronized from Microsoft Entra ID to GitHub Enterprise Server in the **Attribute-Mapping** section. The attributes selected as **Matching** properties are used to match the groups in GitHub Enterprise Server for update operations. Select the **Save** button to commit any changes.\n+\n+    |Attribute|Type|\n+    |---|---|\n+    |`displayName`|String|\n+    |`externalId`|String|\n+    |`members`|Reference|\n+\n+1. To configure scoping filters, refer to the following instructions provided in the [Scoping filter article](~/identity/app-provisioning/define-conditional-rules-for-provisioning-user-accounts.md).\n+\n+1. To enable the Microsoft Entra provisioning service for GitHub Enterprise Server, change the **Provisioning Status** to **On** in the **Settings** section.\n+\n+    ![Screenshot of the Provisioning Status toggle switched to the On position.](common/provisioning-toggle-on.png)\n+\n+1. Define the users and/or groups that you would like to provision to GitHub Enterprise Server by choosing the desired values in **Scope** in the **Settings** section.\n+\n+    ![Screenshot of the Provisioning Scope dropdown with available options.](common/provisioning-scope.png)\n+\n+1. When you're ready to provision, select **Save**.\n+\n+    ![Screenshot of the Save button highlighted to save the provisioning configuration.](common/provisioning-configuration-save.png)\n+\n+This operation starts the initial synchronization cycle of all users and/or groups defined in **Scope** in the **Settings** section. The initial cycle takes longer to perform than subsequent cycles, which occur approximately every 40 minutes as long as the Microsoft Entra provisioning service is running. \n+\n+## Step 6: Monitor your deployment\n+\n+[!INCLUDE [monitor-deployment.md](~/identity/saas-apps/includes/monitor-deployment.md)]\n+\n+## Change log\n+\n+* 02/18/2021 - Added support for Groups provisioning.\n+* 08/19/2025 - Updated links and mentions of \"GitHub AE\" to \"GitHub Enterprise Server\" to reflect the current product name.\n+\n+## Additional resources\n+\n+* [Managing user account provisioning for Enterprise Apps](~/identity/app-provisioning/configure-automatic-user-provisioning-portal.md)\n+* [What is application access and single sign-on with Microsoft Entra ID?](~/identity/enterprise-apps/what-is-single-sign-on.md)\n+\n+## Related content\n+\n+* [Learn how to review logs and get reports on provisioning activity](~/identity/app-provisioning/check-status-user-account-provisioning.md)"
  },

    "patch": "@@ -1,10 +1,10 @@\n ---\n-title: Configure GitHub Enterprise Server for Single sign-on with Microsoft Entra ID\n+title: Configure GitHub Enterprise Server for Single Sign-on with Microsoft Entra ID\n description: Learn how to configure single sign-on between Microsoft Entra ID and GitHub Enterprise Server.\n \n author: nguhiu\n manager: mwongerapk\n-ms.reviewer: celested\n+ms.reviewer: jomondi\n ms.service: entra-id\n ms.subservice: saas-apps\n \n@@ -17,7 +17,7 @@ ms.author: gideonkiratu\n \n # Configure GitHub Enterprise Server for Single sign-on with Microsoft Entra ID\n \n-In this article,  you learn how to integrate GitHub Enterprise Server with Microsoft Entra ID. When you integrate GitHub Enterprise Server with Microsoft Entra ID, you can:\n+In this article, you learn how to integrate GitHub Enterprise Server with Microsoft Entra ID. When you integrate GitHub Enterprise Server with Microsoft Entra ID, you can:\n \n * Control in Microsoft Entra ID who has access to GitHub Enterprise Server.\n * Enable your users to be automatically signed-in to GitHub Enterprise Server with their Microsoft Entra accounts.\n@@ -28,19 +28,19 @@ In this article,  you learn how to integrate GitHub Enterprise Server with Micro\n To get started, you need the following items:\n \n * A Microsoft Entra subscription. If you don't have a subscription, you can get a [free account](https://azure.microsoft.com/free/).\n-* GitHub Enterprise Server, ready for [initialization](https://docs.github.com/github-ae@latest/admin/configuration/initializing-github-ae).\n+* GitHub Enterprise Server, ready for [initialization](https://docs.github.com/enterprise-server/admin/overview/about-github-enterprise-server).\n * Along with Cloud Application Administrator, Application Administrator can also add or manage applications in Microsoft Entra ID.\n For more information, see [Azure built-in roles](~/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md).\n \n ## Scenario description\n \n-In this article,  you configure and test Microsoft Entra SSO in a test environment.\n+In this article, you configure and test Microsoft Entra SSO in a test environment.\n \n * GitHub Enterprise Server supports **SP** and **IDP** initiated SSO.\n * GitHub Enterprise Server supports **Just In Time** user provisioning.\n-* GitHub Enterprise Server supports [Automated user provisioning](github-ae-provisioning-tutorial.md).\n+* GitHub Enterprise Server supports [Automated user provisioning](./github-enterprise-server-provisioning-tutorial.md).\n \n-## Adding GitHub Enterprise Server from the gallery\n+## Add GitHub Enterprise Server from the gallery\n \n To configure the integration of GitHub Enterprise Server into Microsoft Entra ID, you need to add GitHub Enterprise Server from the gallery to your list of managed SaaS apps.\n \n@@ -92,51 +92,48 @@ Follow these steps to enable Microsoft Entra SSO.\n      In the **Sign on URL** text box, type a URL using the following pattern:\n     `https://<YOUR-GITHUB-ENTERPRISE-SERVER-HOSTNAME>/sso`\n \n-\t> [!NOTE]\n-\t> These values aren't real. Update these values with the actual Identifier, Reply URL and Sign on URL. Contact [GitHub Enterprise Server Client support team](mailto:support@github.com) to get these values. You can also refer to the patterns shown in the **Basic SAML Configuration** section.\n+    > [!NOTE]\n+    > These values aren't real. Update these values with the actual Identifier, Reply URL and Sign on URL. Contact [GitHub Enterprise Server Client support team](mailto:support@github.com) to get these values. You can also refer to the patterns shown in the **Basic SAML Configuration** section.\n \n 1. GitHub Enterprise Server application expects the SAML assertions in a specific format, which requires you to add custom attribute mappings to your SAML token attributes configuration. The following screenshot shows the list of default attributes.\n \n-\t![Screenshot shows the image of Enterprise Server application.](common/default-attributes.png \"Attributes\")\n+    ![Screenshot shows the image of Enterprise Server application.](common/default-attributes.png \"Attributes\")\n \n 1. Edit **User Attributes & Claims**.\n \n-1. Select **Add new claim** and enter the name as **administrator** in the textbox (the **administrator** value is case-sensitive).\n+1. Select **Add new claim** and enter the name as `administrator` in the textbox (the `administrator` value is case-sensitive).\n \n 1. Expand **Claim conditions** and select **Members** from **User type**.\n \n 1. Select **Select groups** and search for the **Group** you want to include this claim, where its members should be administrators for GHES.\n \n-1. Select **Attribute** for **Source** and enter **true** (without quotes) for the **Value**. \n+1. Select **Attribute** for **Source** and enter `true` (without quotes) for the **Value**. \n \n 1. Select **Save**.\n \n     ![Screenshot shows to manage claim for attributes.](./media/github-ae-tutorial/administrator.png \"Claims\")\n \n-    > [!NOTE]\n-    > To know the instructions on how to add a claim, please follow the [link](https://docs.github.com/en/github-ae@latest/admin/authentication/configuring-authentication-and-provisioning-for-your-enterprise-using-azure-ad).\n-\n 1. On the **Set up single sign-on with SAML** page, in the **SAML Signing Certificate** section,  find **Certificate (Base64)** and select **Download** to download the certificate and save it on your computer.\n \n-\t![Screenshot shows the Certificate download link.](common/certificatebase64.png \"Certificate\")\n+    ![Screenshot shows the Certificate download link.](common/certificatebase64.png \"Certificate\")\n \n 1. On the **Set up GitHub Enterprise Server** section, copy the appropriate URL(s) based on your requirement.\n \n-\t![Screenshot shows to copy appropriate configuration U R L.](common/copy-configuration-urls.png \"Metadata\")\n+    ![Screenshot shows to copy appropriate configuration U R L.](common/copy-configuration-urls.png \"Metadata\")\n \n <a name='create-an-azure-ad-test-user'></a>\n \n [!INCLUDE [create-assign-users-sso.md](~/identity/saas-apps/includes/create-assign-users-sso.md)]\n \n ## Configure GitHub Enterprise Server SSO\n \n-To configure SSO on GitHub Enterprise Server side, you need to follow the instructions mentioned [here](https://docs.github.com/github-ae@latest/admin/authentication/configuring-saml-single-sign-on-for-your-enterprise#enabling-saml-sso).\n+To configure SSO on GitHub Enterprise Server side, you need to follow the instructions mentioned [here](https://docs.github.com/enterprise-server/admin/managing-iam/using-saml-for-enterprise-iam/configuring-saml-single-sign-on-for-your-enterprise).\n \n ### Create GitHub Enterprise Server test user\n \n In this section, a user called B.Simon is created in GitHub Enterprise Server. GitHub Enterprise Server supports just-in-time user provisioning, which is enabled by default. There's no action item for you in this section. If a user doesn't already exist in GitHub Enterprise Server, a new one is created after authentication.\n \n-GitHub Enterprise Server also supports automatic user provisioning, you can find more details [here](./github-ae-provisioning-tutorial.md) on how to configure automatic user provisioning.\n+GitHub Enterprise Server also supports automatic user provisioning. You can find more details [here](./github-enterprise-server-provisioning-tutorial.md) on how to configure automatic user provisioning.\n \n ## Test SSO \n \n@@ -156,6 +153,6 @@ You can also use Microsoft My Apps to test the application in any mode. ]. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary.","role":"user"}
ai_summary.Response: This commit introduces a new document detailing how to use Microsoft Graph to check web content filtering categories for Global Secure Access. It also renames and updates documentation related to GitHub Enterprise Server, including its single sign-on and provisioning tutorials, aligning with product name changes and adding new redirects. Several other documents have minor updates, including date changes, additions of service/subservice tags, and minor text adjustments.

]. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary."}
ai_summary.Response: These commits primarily update metadata across various Microsoft Entra ID documentation pages. The key change is the consistent addition of `ms.subservice: workforce` to a wide range of articles, including primers, developer guides, tutorials, and scenario-specific pages. This adjustment likely categorises or tags these documents more accurately within the broader Microsoft Entra product suite, potentially for better organisation or searchability. Additionally, a minor correction was made to an example query in the dynamic membership documentation to refine the `deviceOSType` attribute for iOS devices.

ai_summary.Response:
The documentation for Microsoft Entra External ID has been updated to include information on regional opt-in for MFA telephony verification in August 2025. Several existing articles have also seen updates, with a focus on new videos, API changes, and general availability announcements for features like SAML/WS-Fed federation.

Additionally, the FAQ for Global Secure Access has been clarified to specify the required cryptographic algorithms for TLS inspection certificates, supporting SHA-256, SHA-384, and SHA-512.

Finally, an update to the Microsoft Entra ID Governance documentation clarifies that the execution user scope list displays all users meeting the conditions, regardless of whether they have already been processed by the workflow.

ai_summary.Response: The commit modifies a documentation page regarding checking workflow execution scope in Microsoft Entra ID. It clarifies that the displayed list of users under the execution scope includes all users meeting the criteria, regardless of whether they have already been processed by the workflow. Additionally, a note is updated to emphasize that the workflow engine evaluates users irrespective of prior processing, and the results' timeliness depends on recent changes to execution conditions or user attributes.

ai_summary.Response: This update focuses on documentation improvements and corrections. It clarifies that the new bulk operations service in Microsoft Entra ID currently supports exports for Groups, Devices, and Users, with support for additional entities like Enterprise applications to be added later, and notes that template localisation is not supported. Additionally, it updates the date for several documentation articles and refines the prerequisites for enabling TLS 1.2 Only Mode for Microsoft Entra Domain Services, specifying the required roles. It also adds a note regarding the direct assignment of roles for Microsoft Entra Connect installations and general documentation clean-ups.

A new section for August 2025 has been added, detailing an update to the "Microsoft Enterprise SSO plug-in for Apple devices" article, specifically mentioning adjustments to Apple SSO, the token protection image, and troubleshooting secure enclave issues.     "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/8a793537d67debb0d7536fe20348de489e865733/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fmedia%2Fremote-network-resilience%2Fzone-redundancy.png",

    "sha": "cdaf8e4b1b4923878925087656098ff0bdf2aa26",
    "filename": "docs/global-secure-access/remote-network-resilience.md",
    "status": "added",
    "additions": 68,
    "deletions": 0,
    "changes": 68,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/8a793537d67debb0d7536fe20348de489e865733/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fremote-network-resilience.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/8a793537d67debb0d7536fe20348de489e865733/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fremote-network-resilience.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fremote-network-resilience.md?ref=8a793537d67debb0d7536fe20348de489e865733",
    "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,68 @@\n+---\n+title: Enhance Remote Network Resilience with Global Secure Access\n+description: \"This article provides techniques to improve remote network resilience with Global Secure Access.\"\n+author: HULKsmashGithub\n+ms.author: jayrusso\n+ms.service: global-secure-access\n+ms.topic: best-practice\n+ms.date: 09/02/2025\n+manager: dougeby\n+ms.reviewer: abhijeetsinha\n+ai-usage: ai-assisted\n+\n+#customer intent: As a network administrator, I want to improve remote network resilience so that users can maintain connectivity during disruptions.\n+\n+---\n+\n+# Best practices for Global Secure Access remote network resilience\n+This article provides actionable recommendations to enhance the resilience of remote networks. To ensure optimal deployment and performance of Global Secure Access remote network connectivity, follow these best practices:\n+ \n+## Configure redundant tunnels and failovers\n+Configure multiple Internet Protocol Security (IPsec) tunnels from the customer premises equipment (CPE) to different Global Secure Access edges or POPs. \n+\n+### Zone redundancy \n+The **Zone redundancy** option creates two IPsec tunnels in different availability zones, but within the same Azure region. \n+\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/remote-network-resilience/zone-redundancy.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the Connectivity step, with the Add a link pane showing the Zone redundancy menu option.\":::   \n+\n+### Geographic redundancy\n+You can also achieve redundancy by creating a new remote network in a different geographic region. You can use the same CPE configuration to set up IPsec tunnels in the secondary remote network.  \n+\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/remote-network-resilience/geographic-redundancy.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the list of remote networks in multiple geographic regions.\":::   \n+\n+Use the CPE's management console to assign weights to these IPsec tunnels and decide how to route traffic through them. \n+\n+|Tunnel weighting  |Traffic routing  |\n+|---------|---------|\n+|Equal split     | active-active        |\n+|Primary/secondary     | active-standby        |\n+\n+### Dynamic route learning\n+Use Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) for dynamic route learning. If BGP isn't supported on the device, set up static routes with appropriate metrics. \n+\n+## Set up CPE according to your desired security posture\n+Configure CPE based on whether your business prioritizes security or productivity.\n+\n+### Prioritize security\n+If you prioritize security, prevent user traffic from going to the destination without first going through Global Secure Access. To do so, statically route traffic over the IPsec tunnel with Global Secure Access without setting up the default route.\n+\n+### Prioritize productivity\n+If you prioritize productivity, set up a default route for traffic. This way, if a Global Secure Access VPN gateway or backend service goes down, user traffic continues directly through the default route.\n+\n+> [!IMPORTANT]\n+> **Recommendation**: Set up a default route and configure an IP SLA Layer 7 health probe to monitor the endpoint.\n+\n+To set up a default route:\n+1. Configure an IP SLA Layer 7 health probe to monitor the endpoint `http://m365.remote-network.edgediagnostic.globalsecureaccess.microsoft.com:6544/ping`. For guidance, see [How to create a remote network with Global Secure Access](how-to-create-remote-networks.md).\n+1. Alternatively, set the probe to monitor IP address `198.18.1.101`. Statically send these IP addresses over the Global Secure Access IPsec tunnel from your CPE. We're adding this IP address to the Microsoft 365 BGP route advertisement.\n+\n+> [!NOTE]\n+> These endpoints are accessible only through Global Secure Access remote network connectivity.\n+\n+## Configure monitoring and observability\n+Monitor traffic logs and remote network health events by exporting them to your Log Analytics workspace. Set up Azure Monitor alert rules to track the health of your workspace. For more information, see [What are remote network health logs?](how-to-remote-network-health-logs.md).\n+\n+## Related content\n+\n+- [Understand remote network connectivity](concept-remote-network-connectivity.md)\n+- [How to create a remote network with Global Secure Access](how-to-create-remote-networks.md)"
  },

]. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary."}
ai_summary.Response: This commit introduces a new article on enhancing remote network resilience with Global Secure Access, providing guidance on configuring redundant tunnels, zone redundancy, and geographic redundancy. It also updates existing documentation on remote network connectivity and creation to include a link to this new resilience guidance and adjust the review date. Additionally, the table of contents has been updated to reflect the addition of the new article.

{"content":"The following is the commit files that have changed: [
  {
    "sha": "0b63add1f973ea93f9a13284804afddbd3cd6079",
    "filename": "docs/global-secure-access/how-to-install-android-client.md",
    "status": "modified",
    "additions": 74,
    "deletions": 106,
    "changes": 180,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/e0534783de13b951286dbc84e165165587617017/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fhow-to-install-android-client.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/e0534783de13b951286dbc84e165165587617017/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fhow-to-install-android-client.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fglobal-secure-access%2Fhow-to-install-android-client.md?ref=e0534783de13b951286dbc84e165165587617017",
    "patch": "@@ -3,132 +3,100 @@ title: The Global Secure Access Client for Android\n description: The Global Secure Access client secures network traffic at the end-user device. This article describes how to download and install the Android client app.\n ms.service: global-secure-access\n ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 02/25/2025\n+ms.date: 09/02/2025\n ms.author: jayrusso\n author: HULKsmashGithub\n manager: dougeby\n-ms.reviewer: dhruvinrshah\n+ms.reviewer: cagautham\n ms.custom: sfi-image-nochange\n # Customer intent: As an administrator, I want to set up and deploy the Global Secure Access mobile client for Android devices.\n ---\n # Global Secure Access client for Android\n \n The Global Secure Access client can be deployed to compliant Android devices using Microsoft Intune and Microsoft Defender for Endpoint on Android. The Android client is built into the Defender for Endpoint Android app, which streamlines how your end users connect to Global Secure Access. The Global Secure Access Android client makes it easier for your end users to connect to the resources they need without having to manually configure VPN settings on their devices.\n \n-This article explains the prerequisites and how to deploy the client onto Android devices.\n+This article explains how to deploy the Global Secure Access client onto Android devices.\n \n ## Prerequisites\n \n-- The product requires licensing. For details, see the licensing section of [What is Global Secure Access](overview-what-is-global-secure-access.md). If needed, you can [purchase licenses or get trial licenses](https://aka.ms/azureadlicense).\n-- You must enable at least one Global Secure Access [traffic forwarding profile](concept-traffic-forwarding.md).\n-- Device installation permissions on the device are required for installation.\n-- Android devices must be running Android 10.0 or later.\n-- Android devices must be Microsoft Entra registered devices.\n-  - Devices not managed by your organization must have the Microsoft Authenticator app must be installed.\n-  - Devices not managed through Intune must have the Company Portal app installed.\n-  - Device enrollment is required for Intune device compliance policies to be enforced.\n+- The product requires licensing. For details, see the licensing section of [What is Global Secure Access](overview-what-is-global-secure-access.md). If needed, [purchase licenses or get trial licenses](https://aka.ms/azureadlicense).\n+- Enable at least one Global Secure Access [traffic forwarding profile](concept-traffic-forwarding.md).\n+- You need device installation permissions to install the client.\n+- Android devices need to run Android 10.0 or later.\n+- Android devices need to be Microsoft Entra registered devices.\n+  - Devices not managed by your organization need to have the Microsoft Authenticator app installed.\n+  - Devices not managed through Intune need to have the Company Portal app installed.\n+  - Device enrollment is required to enforce Intune device compliance policies.\n \n ### Known limitations\n \n [!INCLUDE [known-limitations-include](../includes/known-limitations-include.md)]\n \n ## Supported scenarios\n \n-Global Secure Access client for Android supports deployment for the legacy Device Administrator and Android Enterprise scenarios. The following Android Enterprise scenarios are supported:\n+The Global Secure Access client for Android supports deployment in these Android Enterprise scenarios:\n \n-- Corporate-owned, fully managed user devices.\n-- Corporate-owned devices with a work profile.\n-- Personal devices with a work profile.\n+- Corporate-owned, fully managed user devices\n+- Corporate-owned devices with a work profile\n+- Personal devices with a work profile\n \n ### Non-Microsoft mobile device management\n \n-Non-Microsoft mobile device management (MDM) scenarios are also supported. In these scenarios, known as *Global Secure Access only mode*, you only need to enable a traffic forwarding profile and configure the app according to the vendor documentation.\n-\n-## Deploy Microsoft Defender for Endpoint Android\n-\n-There are several combinations of deployment modes and scenarios for using the Global Secure Access client for Android.\n-\n-Once you enable a traffic forwarding profile and configure your network, the Global Secure Access Android client appears in the Defender app automatically; however, the Global Secure Access client is disabled by default. Users can enable the client from the Defender app. The steps to enable the client are provided in the [Confirm Global Secure Access appears in Defender app](#confirm-global-secure-access-appears-in-defender-app) section.\n-\n-### [Device Administrator](#tab/device-administrator)\n-\n-This legacy enrollment mode allows you to deploy Defender for Endpoint on Android with Microsoft Intune Company Portal - Device Administrator enrolled devices.\n-\n-The high level process is as follows:\n-\n-1. Deploy Defender to Intune enrolled Android devices.\n-\n-1. [Enable at least one traffic forwarding profile](concept-traffic-forwarding.md) if Defender is already deployed.\n-\n-1. [Confirm Global Secure Access appears in the Defender app](#confirm-global-secure-access-appears-in-defender-app).\n-\n-The detailed process for deploying Defender is as follows:\n-\n-1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Intune admin center](https://intune.microsoft.com/) as an [Intune Administrator](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#intune-administrator).\n-1. Browse to **Apps** > **Android** > **Add** > **Android store app** > **Select**.\n-\n-    ![Screenshot of the add Android app store options.](media/how-to-install-android-client/intune-add-android-store-app.png)\n-\n-1. Provide a **Name**, **Description**, and **Publisher**.\n-1. Enter the URL in the **Appstore URL** field.\n-    - `https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.microsoft.scmx`\n-1. Leave all other fields as their default values and select **Next**.\n-\n-    ![Screenshot of the completed fields.](media/how-to-install-android-client/intune-add-defender-app-fields.png)\n-\n-1. In the **Required** section, select **Add group**, then select the groups to assign the app to and select **Next**.\n-    - The selected group should consist of your Intune enrolled users.\n-    - You can edit or add more groups later.\n-\n-    ![Screenshot of the add groups steps.](media/how-to-install-android-client/intune-add-group.png)\n-\n-1. On the **Review + create** tab, confirm the information is correct and select **Create**.\n-1. On the new app details page, select **Device install status** and confirm the app is installed.\n-\n-**Users need to enable the client in the Defender app. It's disabled by default.** Proceed to the next section to confirm the app is installed and for how to enable the client.\n-\n-### [Android Enterprise](#tab/android-enterprise)\n-\n-Follow these steps to add the Microsoft Defender for Endpoint app into your managed Google Play store.\n-\n-The high level process is as follows:\n-\n-1. Deploy Defender on Android Enterprise enrolled devices.\n-\n-1. [Enable at least one traffic forwarding profile](concept-traffic-forwarding.md).\n-\n-1. [Confirm Global Secure Access appears in the Microsoft Defender for Endpoint app](#confirm-global-secure-access-appears-in-defender-app).\n-\n-The detailed process for deploying to the Google Play store is as follows:\n-\n-1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Intune admin center](https://intune.microsoft.com/) as an [Intune Administrator](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#intune-administrator).\n-1. Browse to **Apps** > **Android** > **Add** > **Managed Google Play app** > **Select**.\n-\n-    ![Screenshot of the add Google Play app options.](media/how-to-install-android-client/intune-add-google-play-app.png)\n-\n-1. On the managed Google Play page, search for **Microsoft Defender** and select it from the search results.\n-1. On the details page for Microsoft Defender, select the **Select** button.\n-1. Select the **Sync** button in the upper-left corner. This step syncs Defender with your apps list.\n-\n-    ![Screenshot of the Defender app details, with the Sync button highlighted.](media/how-to-install-android-client/intune-sync-google-play.png)\n-\n-1. Select the **Refresh** button on the Android apps screen so Microsoft Defender for Endpoint appears in the list.\n-1. Select **Microsoft Defender** from the app list and browse to **Properties** > **Assignments** > **Edit**.\n-\n-    ![Screenshot of the Edit option for assigning groups.](media/how-to-install-android-client/intune-google-assignments-edit.png)\n-\n-1. In the **Required** section, select **Add group**, then select the groups to assign the app to and select **Next**.\n-1. Select **Review + save** and once the details are confirmed, select **Save**.\n-\n-    ![Screenshot of the Add group option.](media/how-to-install-android-client/intune-google-add-group.png)\n-\n-After you assign a group, the app is automatically installed in the *work profile* during the next sync of the device via the Company Portal app.\n-\n-**Users need to enable the client in the Defender app. It's disabled by default.** Proceed to the next section to confirm the app is installed and for how to enable the client.\n-\n----\n-\n-## Confirm Global Secure Access appears in Defender app\n+The Global Secure Access client also supports non-Microsoft mobile device management (MDM) scenarios. These scenarios, known as *Global Secure Access only mode*, require enabling a traffic forwarding profile and configuring the app based on the vendor documentation.\n+\n+## Deploy Microsoft Defender for Endpoint on Android\n+\n+To deploy Microsoft Defender for Endpoint on Android, create an MDM profile and configure Global Secure Access. \n+\n+1. In the [Microsoft Intune admin center](https://intune.microsoft.com/#home), go to **Apps** > **Android** > **Manage Apps** > **Configuration**. \n+1. Select **+ Create**, and then select **Managed devices**. The **Create app configuration policy** form opens.\n+1. On the **Basics** tab:\n+    1. Enter a **Name**.\n+    1. Set the **Platform** to **Android Enterprise**.\n+    1. Set the **Profile type** to **Fully Managed, Dedicated, and Corporate-Owned Work Profile Only**.\n+    1. Set the **Targeted app** to **Microsoft Defender**. \n+1. Select **Next**.\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/how-to-install-android-client/create-policy-basics.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the Create app configuration policy on the Basics tab.\" lightbox=\"media/how-to-install-android-client/create-policy-basics-expanded.png\":::   \n+\n+1. On the **Settings** tab:\n+    1. Set **Configuration settings format** to **Use configuration designer**.\n+    1. Use the JSON editor to configure the disabled configuration keys:\n+        1. Select the **+ Add** button.\n+        1. In the search field, type `global` and select these configuration keys:\n+            - **Global Secure Access** (this key is required to enable Global Secure Access). \n+            - **GlobalSecureAccessPrivateChannel** (this optional key enables Global Secure Access Private channel). \n+        1. Set the appropriate values for each configuration key according to the following table: \n+ \n+        | Configuration key                | Value    | Details   |\n+        |----------------------------------|----------|-----------|\n+        | Global Secure Access             | No value | Global Secure Access isn't enabled and the tile isn't visible. |\n+        |                                  | 0        | Global Secure Access isn't enabled and the tile isn't visible. |\n+        |                                  | 1        | The tile is visible and defaults to false (disabled state). The user can enable or disable Global Secure Access using the toggle in the app. |\n+        |                                  | 2        | The tile is visible and defaults to true (enabled state). The user can override Global Secure Access. The user can enable or disable Global Secure Access using the toggle in the app. |\n+        |                                  | 3        | The tile is visible and defaults to true (enabled state). The user **can't** disable Global Secure Access. |\n+        | GlobalSecureAccessPrivateChannel | No value | Global Secure Access defaults to value 2 behavior. |\n+        |                                  | 0        | Private Access isn't enabled and the toggle option isn't visible to the user. |\n+        |                                  | 1        | The Private Access toggle is visible and defaults to the disabled state. The user can enable or disable Private Access. |\n+        |                                  | 2        | The Private Access toggle is visible and defaults to the disabled state. The user can enable or disable Private Access. |\n+        |                                  | 3        | The Private Access toggle is visible but grayed out, and defaults to the enabled state. The user **can't** disable Private Access. |\n+\n+    > [!NOTE]\n+    > The **GlobalSecureAccessPA** configuration key is no longer supported.   \n+\n+6. Select **Next**. \n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/how-to-install-android-client/create-policy-settings.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the Create app configuration policy on the Settings tab.\" lightbox=\"media/how-to-install-android-client/create-policy-settings-expanded.png\":::   \n+\n+1. On the **Scope tags** tab, configure scope tags as needed and select **Next**.\n+1. On the **Assignments** tab, select **+ Add groups** to assign the configuration policy and enable Global Secure Access.\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/how-to-install-android-client/create-policy-assignments.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the Create app configuration policy on the Assignments tab.\" lightbox=\"media/how-to-install-android-client/create-policy-assignments-expanded.png\":::   \n+\n+> [!TIP]\n+> To enable the policy for all but a few specific users, select **Add all devices** in the **Included groups** section. Then, add the users or groups to exclude in the **Excluded groups** section.\n+\n+9. Select **Next**.\n+1. Review the configuration summary and select **Create**. \n+\n+## Confirm Global Secure Access appears in the Defender app\n \n Because the Android client is integrated with Defender for Endpoint, it's helpful to understand the end user experience. The client appears in the Defender dashboard after onboarding to Global Secure Access. Onboarding happens by enabling a traffic forwarding profile.\n \n@@ -138,19 +106,19 @@ Because the Android client is integrated with Defender for Endpoint, it's helpfu\n \n ![Screenshot of the disabled Global Secure Access client.](media/how-to-install-android-client/defender-global-secure-access-disabled.png)\n \n-To view the details of the client, tap on the tile on the dashboard. When enabled and working properly, the client displays an \"Enabled\" message. The date and time for when the client connected to Global Secure Access also appears.\n+To view client details, tap the tile on the dashboard. When enabled and working properly, the client shows an \"Enabled\" message. It also shows the date and time when the client connected to Global Secure Access.\n \n ![Screenshot of the enabled Global Secure Access client.](media/how-to-install-android-client/defender-global-secure-access-enabled.png)\n \n-If the client is unable to connect, a toggle appears to disable the service. Users can come back later to try enabling the client.\n+If the client can't connect, a toggle appears to disable the service. Users can return later to enable the client.\n \n ![Screenshot of the Global Secure Access client that is unable to connect.](media/how-to-install-android-client/defender-global-secure-access-unable.png)\n \n ## Troubleshooting\n \n-The Global Secure Access tile doesn't appear after onboarding the tenant to the service. Restart the Defender app.\n+If the Global Secure Access tile doesn't appear after onboarding the tenant to the service, restart the Defender app.\n \n-When attempting to access a Private Access application, the connection might time out after a successful interactive sign-in. Reloading the application through a web browser refresh should resolve the issue.\n+When you try to access a Private Access application, the connection might time out after a successful interactive sign-in. Reload the application by refreshing the web browser.\n \n ## Related content\n - [About Microsoft Defender for Endpoint on Android](/microsoft-365/security/defender-endpoint/microsoft-defender-endpoint-android)"

    "patch": "@@ -32,16 +32,11 @@ For a list of supported applications and how to configure policies, see the foll\n \n Conditional Access App Control uses a reverse proxy architecture and is uniquely integrated with Microsoft Entra Conditional Access. Microsoft Entra Conditional Access allows you to enforce access controls on your organization’s apps based on certain conditions. The conditions define what user or group of users, cloud apps, and locations and networks a Conditional Access policy applies to. After you determine the conditions, you can route users to [Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps](/defender-cloud-apps/what-is-defender-for-cloud-apps) where you can protect data with Conditional Access App Control by applying access and session controls.\n \n-Conditional Access App Control enables user app access and sessions to be monitored and controlled in real time based on access and session policies. Access and session policies are used within the Defender for Cloud Apps portal to refine filters and set actions to take. With the access and session policies, you can:\n+Conditional Access App Control enables user app access and sessions to be monitored and controlled in real time based on access and session policies. Access and session policies are used within the Defender for Cloud Apps portal to refine filters and set actions to take. \n \n-- Prevent data exfiltration: You can block the download, cut, copy, and print of sensitive documents on, for example, unmanaged devices.\n-- Protect on download: Instead of blocking the download of sensitive documents, you can require documents to be labeled and protected with Azure Information Protection. This action ensures the document is protected and user access is restricted in a potentially risky session.\n-- Prevent upload of unlabeled files: Before a sensitive file is uploaded, distributed, and used, it’s important to make sure that the file has the right label and protection. You can ensure that unlabeled files with sensitive content are blocked from being uploaded until the user classifies the content.\n-- Monitor user sessions for compliance (Preview): Risky users are monitored when they sign into apps and their actions are logged from within the session. You can investigate and analyze user behavior to understand where, and under what conditions, session policies should be applied in the future.\n-- Block access (Preview): You can granularly block access for specific apps and users depending on several risk factors. For example, you can block them if they're using client certificates as a form of device management.\n-- Block custom activities: Some apps have unique scenarios that carry risk, for example, sending messages with sensitive content in apps like Microsoft Teams or Slack. In these kinds of scenarios, you can scan messages for sensitive content and block them in real time.\n+This control can be enforced with Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps, where Admins can [Deploy Conditional Access App Control for featured apps](/defender-cloud-apps/proxy-deployment-aad) and [use Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps session policies](/defender-cloud-apps/session-policy-aad).\n \n-For more information, see the article [Deploy Conditional Access App Control for featured apps](/defender-cloud-apps/proxy-deployment-aad).\n+For Microsoft Edge for Business, this control can be enforced with [Microsoft Purview Data Loss Prevention](/purview/dlp-browser-dlp-learn), where Admins can [help prevent users from sharing sensitive info with Cloud Apps in Edge for Business](/purview/dlp-create-policy-prevent-cloud-sharing-from-edge-biz). The Conditional Access App Control **Custom** setting is required for apps included in these policies.\n \n ## Sign-in frequency\n "

    "patch": "@@ -1,38 +1,41 @@\n ---\n-title: Configure adaptive session lifetime policies\n-description: Customize Microsoft Entra authentication session configuration including user sign-in frequency and browser session persistence.\n-\n+title: Adaptive Session Lifetime Policies for Conditional Access\n+description: Learn how to configure adaptive session lifetime policies in Microsoft Entra to manage sign-in frequency and browser session persistence effectively.\n ms.service: entra-id\n ms.subservice: conditional-access\n ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 08/13/2024\n-\n+ms.date: 09/02/2025\n ms.author: joflore\n author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n manager: dougeby\n ms.reviewer: inbarc\n+ms.custom:\n+  - ai-gen-docs-bap\n+  - ai-gen-title\n+  - ai-seo-date:09/02/2025\n+  - ai-gen-description\n ---\n # Configure adaptive session lifetime policies\n \n > [!WARNING]\n-> If you are using the [configurable token lifetime](~/identity-platform/configurable-token-lifetimes.md) feature currently in public preview, please note that we don’t support creating two different policies for the same user or app combination: one with this feature and another one with configurable token lifetime feature. Microsoft retired the configurable token lifetime feature for refresh and session token lifetimes on January 30, 2021 and replaced it with the Conditional Access authentication session management feature.  \n+> If you're using the [configurable token lifetime](~/identity-platform/configurable-token-lifetimes.md) feature currently in public preview, we don't support creating two different policies for the same user or app combination: one with this feature and another with the configurable token lifetime feature. Microsoft retired the configurable token lifetime feature for refresh and session token lifetimes on January 30, 2021, and replaced it with the Conditional Access authentication session management feature.  \n >\n-> Before enabling Sign-in Frequency, make sure other reauthentication settings are disabled in your tenant. If \"Remember MFA on trusted devices\" is enabled, be sure to disable it before using Sign-in frequency, as using these two settings together may lead to prompting users unexpectedly. To learn more about reauthentication prompts and session lifetime, see the article, [Optimize reauthentication prompts and understand session lifetime for Microsoft Entra multifactor authentication](~/identity/authentication/concepts-azure-multi-factor-authentication-prompts-session-lifetime.md).\n+> Before enabling Sign-in Frequency, make sure other reauthentication settings are disabled in your tenant. If \"Remember MFA on trusted devices\" is enabled, disable it before using Sign-in Frequency, as using these two settings together might prompt users unexpectedly. To learn more about reauthentication prompts and session lifetime, see the article, [Optimize reauthentication prompts and understand session lifetime for Microsoft Entra multifactor authentication](~/identity/authentication/concepts-azure-multi-factor-authentication-prompts-session-lifetime.md).\n \n ## Policy deployment\n \n-To make sure that your policy works as expected, the recommended best practice is to test it before rolling it out into production. Ideally, use a test tenant to verify whether your new policy works as intended. For more information, see the article [Plan a Conditional Access deployment](plan-conditional-access.md).\n+To ensure your policy works as expected, test it before rolling it out into production. Use a test tenant to verify that your new policy works as intended. For more information, see the article [Plan a Conditional Access deployment](plan-conditional-access.md).\n \n ### Policy 1: Sign-in frequency control\n \n 1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com) as at least a [Conditional Access Administrator](../role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#conditional-access-administrator).\n 1. Browse to **Entra ID** > **Conditional Access** > **Policies**.\n 1. Select **New policy**.\n-1. Give your policy a name. We recommend that organizations create a meaningful standard for the names of their policies.\n+1. Give your policy a name. Create a meaningful standard for naming policies.\n 1. Choose all required conditions for customer’s environment, including the target cloud apps.\n \n    > [!NOTE]\n-   > It is recommended to set equal authentication prompt frequency for key Microsoft Office apps such as Exchange Online and SharePoint Online for best user experience.\n+   > It's recommended to set equal authentication prompt frequency for key Microsoft 365 apps such as Exchange Online and SharePoint Online for best user experience.\n \n 1. Under **Access controls** > **Session**.\n    1. Select **Sign-in frequency**.\n@@ -51,13 +54,13 @@ To make sure that your policy works as expected, the recommended best practice i\n 1. Choose all required conditions.\n \n    > [!NOTE]\n-   > This control requires to choose \"All Cloud Apps\" as a condition. Browser session persistence is controlled by authentication session token. All tabs in a browser session share a single session token and therefore they all must share persistence state.\n+   > This control requires selecting \"All Cloud Apps\" as a condition. Browser session persistence is controlled by authentication session token. All tabs in a browser session share a single session token and therefore they all must share persistence state.\n \n 1. Under **Access controls** > **Session**.\n    1. Select **Persistent browser session**.\n \n       > [!NOTE]\n-      > Persistent Browser Session configuration in Microsoft Entra Conditional Access overrides the \"Stay signed in?\" setting in the company branding pane for the same user if you have configured both policies.\n+      > Persistent browser session configuration in Microsoft Entra Conditional Access overrides the \"Stay signed in?\" setting in the company branding pane for the same user if both policies are configured.\n \n    1. Select **Create** to create to enable your policy.\n \n-After administrators confirm your settings using [report-only mode](howto-conditional-access-insights-reporting.md), they can move the **Enable policy** toggle from **Report-only** to **On**.\n+After confirming your settings using [report-only mode](howto-conditional-access-insights-reporting.md), move the **Enable policy** toggle from **Report-only** to **On**.\n \n ### Validation\n \n-Use the [What If tool](what-if-tool.md) to simulate a sign-in from the user to the target application and other conditions based on how you configured your policy. The authentication session management controls show up in the result of the tool.\n \n ## Prompt tolerance\n \n-We factor for five minutes of clock skew when **every time** is selected in policy, so that we don’t prompt users more often than once every five minutes. If the user completed MFA in the last 5 minutes, and they hit another Conditional Access policy that requires reauthentication, we don't prompt the user. Over-prompting users for reauthentication can impact their productivity and increase the risk of users approving MFA requests they didn’t initiate. Use \"Sign-in frequency – every time\" only for specific business needs.\n+We account for five minutes of clock skew when **every time** is selected in policy, so we don’t prompt users more often than once every five minutes. If the user completes MFA in the last 5 minutes and encounters another Conditional Access policy that requires reauthentication, we don't prompt the user. Prompting users too often for reauthentication can affect their productivity and increase the risk of users approving MFA requests they didn’t initiate. Use \"Sign-in frequency – every time\" only when there are specific business needs.\n \n ## Known issues\n \n-* If you configure sign-in frequency for mobile devices: Authentication after each sign-in frequency interval could be slow, it can take 30 seconds on average. Also, it could happen across various apps at the same time.\n-* On iOS devices: If an app configures certificates as the first authentication factor and the app has both Sign-in frequency and [Intune mobile application management policies](/mem/intune/apps/app-lifecycle) applied, end-users are blocked from signing in to the app when the policy triggers.\n-* Microsoft Entra Private Access does not yet support setting sign-in frequency to every time. \n+* If you configure sign-in frequency for mobile devices: Authentication after each sign-in frequency interval might be slow and can take 30 seconds on average. See [Plan a Conditional Access deployment](plan-conditional-access.md)."

    "patch": "@@ -5,7 +5,7 @@ description: Create a Conditional Access policy requiring stronger authenticatio\n ms.service: entra-id\n ms.subservice: conditional-access\n ms.topic: how-to\n-ms.date: 09/30/2024\n+ms.date: 09/02/2025\n \n ms.author: joflore\n author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n@@ -14,30 +14,30 @@ ms.reviewer: lhuangnorth\n ---\n # Require phishing-resistant multifactor authentication for administrators\n \n-Accounts that are assigned privileged administrative roles are frequent targets of attackers. Requiring phishing-resistant multifactor authentication (MFA) on those accounts is an easy way to reduce the risk of those accounts being compromised.\n+Accounts with privileged administrative roles are frequent targets of attackers. Requiring phishing-resistant multifactor authentication (MFA) for these accounts reduces the risk of compromise.\n \n > [!CAUTION]\n-> Before creating a policy requiring phishing-resistant multifactor authentication, ensure your administrators have the appropriate methods registered. If you enable this policy without completing this step you risk locking yourself out of your tenant. Administrators can [Configure Temporary Access Pass to register passwordless authentication methods](../authentication/howto-authentication-temporary-access-pass.md) or follow the steps in [Register a passkey (FIDO2)](../authentication/how-to-register-passkey-with-security-key.md).\n+> Before creating a policy requiring phishing-resistant multifactor authentication, make sure your administrators register the appropriate methods. Microsoft Entra ID provides three [built-in authentication strengths](/entra/identity/authentication/concept-authentication-strengths):\n+This article helps your organization create an MFA policy for your environment using authentication strengths. Microsoft Entra ID offers three [built-in authentication strengths](/entra/identity/authentication/concept-authentication-strengths):\n \n - Multifactor authentication strength (less restrictive)\n - Passwordless MFA strength\n-- **Phishing-resistant MFA strength** (most restrictive) recommended in this article\n+- **Phishing-resistant MFA strength** (most restrictive), recommended in this article\n \n-You can use one of the built-in strengths or create a [custom authentication strength](/entra/identity/authentication/concept-authentication-strength-advanced-options) based on the authentication methods you want to require.\n+Use one of the built-in strengths or create a [custom authentication strength](/entra/identity/authentication/concept-authentication-strength-advanced-options) based on the authentication methods you want to require.\n \n-For external user scenarios, the MFA authentication methods that a resource tenant can accept vary depending on whether the user is completing MFA in their home tenant or in the resource tenant. For more information, see [Authentication strength for external users](/entra/identity/authentication/concept-authentication-strength-external-users).\n+For external user scenarios, the MFA authentication methods that a resource tenant accepts vary depending on whether the user completes MFA in their home tenant or in the resource tenant. For more information, see [Authentication strength for external users](/entra/identity/authentication/concept-authentication-strength-external-users).\n \n ## User exclusions\n [!INCLUDE [active-directory-policy-exclusions](~/includes/entra-policy-exclude-user.md)]\n@@ -47,30 +47,30 @@ For external user scenarios, the MFA authentication methods that a resource tena\n ## Create a Conditional Access policy\n \n > [!WARNING]\n-> If you use [external authentication methods](/entra/identity/authentication/how-to-authentication-external-method-manage), these are currently incompatible with authentication strength and you should use the **[Require multifactor authentication](concept-conditional-access-grant.md#require-multifactor-authentication)** grant control.\n+> If you use [external authentication methods](/entra/identity/authentication/how-to-authentication-external-method-manage), these methods are currently incompatible with authentication strengths. Use the **[Require multifactor authentication](concept-conditional-access-grant.md#require-multifactor-authentication)** grant control instead.\n \n 1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com) as at least a [Conditional Access Administrator](../role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#conditional-access-administrator).\n 1. Browse to **Entra ID** > **Conditional Access** > **Policies**.\n 1. Select **New policy**.\n-1. Give your policy a name. We recommend that organizations create a meaningful standard for the names of their policies.\n+1. Name your policy. Create a meaningful naming standard for your organization's policies.\n 1. Under **Assignments**, select **Users or workload identities**.\n    1. Under **Include**, select **Directory roles** and choose at least the previously listed roles.\n    \n       > [!WARNING]\n-      > Conditional Access policies support built-in roles. Conditional Access policies are not enforced for other role types including [administrative unit-scoped](../role-based-access-control/manage-roles-portal.md) or [custom roles](../role-based-access-control/custom-create.md).\n+      > Conditional Access policies support built-in roles. Conditional Access policies aren't enforced for other role types including [administrative unit-scoped](../role-based-access-control/manage-roles-portal.md) or [custom roles](../role-based-access-control/custom-create.md).\n \n-   1. Under **Exclude**, select **Users and groups** and choose your organization's emergency access or break-glass accounts.\n+   1. Under **Exclude**, select **Users and groups**, and choose your organization's emergency access or break-glass accounts.\n 1. Under **Target resources** > **Resources (formerly cloud apps)** > **Include**, select **All resources (formerly 'All cloud apps')**.\n 1. Under **Access controls** > **Grant**, select **Grant access**.\n    1. Select **Require authentication strength**, then select **Phishing-resistant MFA strength** from the list.\n    1. Select **Select**.\n-1. Confirm your settings and set **Enable policy** to **Report-only**.\n-1. Select **Create** to create to enable your policy.\n+1.
